article_title: CareLink numbers drop due to Obamacare, lower jobless rates
article_text:
CareLink numbers drop due to Obamacare, lower jobless rates

Better access to health insurance and a stronger economy have prompted fewer Bexar County residents to enroll in the CareLink financial assistance program at University Health System, officials said.

article_metadata.description: Better access to health insurance and a stronger economy have prompted fewer Bexar County residents to enroll in the CareLink financial assistance program at University Health System, officials said.  The program, which began in 1997, is not an insurance plan or free charity care, but it waives some of the costs patients would otherwise face while allowing them access to a health provider network.  [...] in 2014, the Affordable Care Act allowed qualified consumers to begin receiving federal subsidies to buy private health insurance through a government-run marketplace.  Generally, those tax credits are available to consumers earning household incomes between 100 percent and 400 percent of the federal poverty level.  CareLink provided enrollment help to nearly 8,000 people looking to purchase health insurance through the government-run marketplace last year, said Dr. Virginia Mika, executive director of the program.  Because Texas declined to expand Medicaid eligibility requirements, uninsured Bexar County residents earning incomes below the federal poverty level still don’t have anywhere to turn besides CareLink.
article_metadata.author.name: By Peggy O’Hare, Staff Writer

og.description: Better access to health insurance and a stronger economy have prompted fewer Bexar County residents to enroll in the CareLink financial assistance program at University Health System, officials said. Generally, those tax credits are available to consumers earning household incomes between 100 percent and 400 percent of the federal poverty level.  CareLink provided enrollment help to nearly 8,000 people looking to purchase health insurance through the government-run marketplace last year, said Dr. Virginia Mika, executive director of the program.  Because Texas declined to expand Medicaid eligibility requirements, uninsured Bexar County residents earning incomes below the federal poverty level still don’t have anywhere to turn besides CareLink.
